intro: Pseudogynoxys asplundii, commonly known as the Mexican false mallow, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. It has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its flowers are borne in clusters at the ends of the stems. Pseudogynoxys asplundii is often found in open woodlands and is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance.
